awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Transforming the Organic Chemistry Lab Experience: Implementation and Evaluation of a Reformed Organic Lab Curriculum Across Institutions
awd_abstract_narration:
Organic chemistry is required for college students majoring in a variety of STEM disciplines. Traditionally, this course has been viewed as a gatekeeper and students have considered the laboratory experience as an isolated and irrelevant use of their time. Reformed teaching methods that increase the relevance of the laboratory and increase student success have proven challenging to deliver, especially when laboratories are taught by graduate teaching assistants. This project, which builds on prior NSF-funded work (DUE Awards #1245160 and #1245176), will develop, implement, and study innovative and easy-to-adopt studio-based organic lab modules. These modules will transform the traditional 3-4 hour organic laboratory into a meaningful learning experience involving trouble-shooting problems and honing lab skills. The project is a collaborative effort between a research university (Rochester Institute of Technology) and a community college (Monroe Community College), which will ensure the materials are appropriate for use in both two-year and four-year settings. In collaboration with regional partners, studies will be conducted to evaluate student learning in other settings, as well as the ease of module adoption, student performance, and retention rates.

This project leverages earlier work developing a studio-based organic laboratory curriculum for two-year and four-year colleges, and promoting its broadened development and implementation. Central goals of the project are enhancing students' meaningful learning and engagement with organic chemistry, and developing a model for implementation of reform-based curricula. To determine the impact of this approach, the project will measure student learning and success, and evaluate the ease and fidelity of module adoption at collaborating institutions. Given the diverse population of students across the institutions committed to adopt the materials and the proximity to the National Technical Institute for the Deaf, further studies will identify retention trends for a diverse set of student populations. This will contribute to developing a more diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce. The results will be disseminated broadly via a PI-sponsored conference, peer-reviewed publications, conference presentations, a website, and a textbook partnership.

por.por_cntn:
Collaborative Research: Transforming the Organic Chemistry Lab Experience: Implementation, and Evaluation of a Reformed Organic Lab Curriculum Across Institutions.

 

The project was intended to broaden the implementation and further development of Reformed Experimental Activities (REActivities) for use throughout an organic chemistry lab curriculum at both 2-year and 4-year colleges. REActivities are uniquely delivered labs that philosophically mirror a guided-inquiry approach.  This easy-to-adopt pedagogy was designed to transform the commonplace 3-4 hour organic lab periods into impactful opportunities for students to engage with their peers and instructor all while honing new lab skills. To determine the efficacy of the approach, studies were conducted to evaluate transferability, transportability, student performance, and barriers to adoption.

 

What follows are major outcomes from the life of this project:

  • A LOPUS-inspired observational instrument was created called Evaluation of Lab Instructor Time and Engagement (ELITE) in order to gage the fidelity of implementation when REActivities is adopted across various institutions and with different instructors. Data from an expert instructor of the pedagogy was compared with new adopters and determined to be extremely comparable. Additionally, when the behaviors of instructors using REActivities were compared with those not using REActivies, a noticeable increase in the amount of lecture time was observed when traditionally taught while lecture time is near zero when REActivities are used. It was also striking to see that when instructors engaged with students during REActivities, a consistent 30% of that engagement involved discussions coded as conceptual in nature. This is in stark contrast to the near 0% conceptual discussions coded when instructors taught using traditional methods.
  • The Meaningful Learning in the Lab (MLLI) instrument was utilized to measure the student-reported learning gains when using REActivities. The results of our analysis have shown positive trends longitudinally from first semester organic chemistry lab to second semester organic chemistry lab. The greatest difference is observed for questions coded in the affective domain (how a student feels). Overall, we are led to conclude that students are more confident over time using REActivities and this is informing our future qualitative methods studies.  
  • Sign Language Incorporation in Chemistry Education (SLICE) was the result of our focus on further development of REActivities. Specifically, we looked at the impact of developing a sign language lexicon in organic chemistry and its impact on Deaf students in the course. We created videos to inform both Deaf and hearing students about the signs specific to transition state modeling and created accompanying REActivities to guide students through incorporating the signs. Our work showed significantly improved performance trends for Deaf students over the course of three years when adopting these signs.
  • Covid-19 forced our team to explore alternative approaches to the delivery of REActivities during the pandemic. As a result, a virtual lab experience was created for each REActivity in the workbook. These videos were shared on both the REActivities website: www.reactivities.org and on a dedicated YouTube channel www.youtube.com/c/reactivities. These videos supported many faculty seeking to use materials for online use during the pandemic. With labs back to an in-person format, these impactful videos are now serving as pre-lab preps, post-lab reviews, and instructor training tutorials.

 

The project’s findings were guided by an external evaluator in year three of the award. A total of seven universities were involved in the data collection and study. At the time of this outcomes statement, the project yielded a second edition of the workbook published through Xanedu, two peer-reviewed articles, one manuscript submitted and awaiting peer-review, two more papers in manuscript, a YouTube channel, and a website. The investigators hope to expand this work toward other lab-based disciplines and are preparing two additional grants for submission as a result of this work.
